Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Stress in a Porous Polymeric Membrane Separator in a Lithium-Ion Battery

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) project is to establish a model for the evaluation of stress in a separator in a lithium ion battery. A separator is a membrane that prevents physical contact between the positive and negative electrodes while enabling ionic transport. The integrity of the separator is vital to the performance and reliability of a battery. In a lithium ion battery, non-mechanical stresses arise due to Li intercalation and self heating of the battery. A multi-scale multi-physics model will relate the deformation and stress in battery components to the material properties, design parameters and the battery electrochemical kinetics. The mechanical behavior of a porous polymeric membrane separator saturated with an electrolyte will be investigated experimentally and represented with an extended biphasic poroviscoelastic model.

The multi-scale model will enable the investigation of interactions among different physical processes and advance the understanding on degradation and failure mechanisms in lithium ion batteries. Besides the separator, it will also allow the optimal design of electrodes and battery cells. A durable, light weight rechargeable battery is a key requirement in producing affordable, sustainable electric and hybrid electric vehicles. The modeling approach and the porous viscoelastic model developed here are applicable to other devices and complex material systems. This project will encourage mechanical engineering students to participate in multi-disciplinary research. The findings will be developed into a demonstration for the College of Engineering "K-12 programs," at Michigan State University, to inspire the future generation of engineers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The separator in a Li-ion battery (LIB) play a critical role in the safety of the battery. The separator is a thin, porous membrane that prevents physical contact between the positive and negative electrodes while enabling ionic transport. Separator failure can lead to short circuit and other undesirable events. In LIBs, the separator is subjected to stress due to the volume changes of the active materials during Li insertion and deinsertion with a battery cycle and the temperature variations. To improve the design of separator, the stress in the separator has to be known. Since it is impossible to measure this stress, a multiphysics model was developed. This model considers the species transport, battery kinetics, heat generation and transfer, and the stress and deformation of the battery cell under chemical, thermal and mechanical loads. This model can reveal the stress in the separator in LIB cells in numerical simulations.

The polymeric separators are viscoelastic materials. Their mechanical properties depend on time and temperatures. Experiments were carried out to measure the mechanical behavior of a polypropylene (PP) separator over time, at a range of temperatures, in air,  and in electrolyte solutions. It was found that the PP separator was up to 50% softer when being tested in these solutions. The softening behavior disappeared when the same sample was tested again in air. Molecular dynamics simulations revealed that this phenomenon was due to the strong interaction between the solvent molecules and the fibrous amorphous regions in the porous polymer.

This research has helped the scientists to design better separators. The multiphysics model helped us to understand the complex coupling relationships in a battery. This work laid the foundation for modeling the next generation LIBs with higher energy density and other devices involving Multiphysics.
